reg_pit.title:
Petroleum Storage and Distribution Facilities
Storm Water Regulation

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "total extractable hydrocarbons" was added by BC Reg 177/2023, effective September 1, 2023.
Section 3 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 177/2023, effective September 1, 2023.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator may introduce effluent into the environment from a petroleum storage and distribution facility if the total extractable hydrocarbon in the effluent at any time does not exceed 15Â mg/litre.

change.changenote: Schedule 2 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 177/2023, effective September 1, 2023.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Effluent samples for the determination of total extractable hydrocarbons must be obtained as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if possible, the sample must be obtained at the point that the effluent exits the treatment facility and enters the environment;

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All equipment which comes into contact with the sample must before the sample is obtained be decontaminated by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: rinsing the equipment with de-ionized water,
scrubbing the equipment with laboratory grade detergent, and
triple rinsing the equipment with de-ionized water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All samples of subsurface liquid must be obtained using a sampling device which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allows a person to obtain a sample of effluent from below the surface of a separator without contaminating the sample with material at the surface of the separator, and
is decontaminated as set out in subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Samples must be stored in only one container from the time they are taken to the time they are delivered to a laboratory for analysis.
Samples must be preserved by adding sufficient acid to the sample immediately after obtaining it to cause the pH of the sample/acid mixture to be less than 2.

Samples must be transferred immediately to a cooler after they are taken and stored as close as possible to 4 degrees centigrade without freezing the sample until they are delivered to a laboratory for analysis.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The analytical method to be used in the determination of total extractable hydrocarbons is described in "Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Waste", Third Edition, 1986, SW-846, Methods 3510/8000A, published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; and using extraction with methylene chloride, volume reduction, and analysis by capillary gas chromatography with flame ionization detection.
